definition: **noun / historical.** A wider [groove](../g/groove-wear.md) format used on early LPs and most 78-RPM records before the modern micro-groove standard. Requires a larger stylus tip (around 3 mil). Macro-groove records, also called standard groove or coarse groove, featured grooves approximately 0.003 inches (3 mils) wide, compared to the 0.001-inch (1 mil) width of micro-grooves introduced by Columbia in 1948. This wider spacing limited playing time to roughly 4-5 minutes per 10-inch 78-RPM side, necessitating frequent disc changes for longer performances. The transition to micro-groove technology enabled the LP format to hold 20-25 minutes per side at 33⅓ RPM, revolutionizing the album concept. Playing macro-groove records with a modern micro-groove stylus causes accelerated wear and poor sound quality; period-correct 78-RPM cartridges with 3-mil spherical or truncated styli are essential for proper playback. Collectors of early jazz, classical, and pre-1950 popular music must maintain dedicated macro-groove playback systems. Some early LPs pressed between 1948-1950 used macro-grooves during the transition period, creating rare variants that require careful identification and appropriate stylus selection.
etymology: From Greek 'makros' (large) + 'groove,' coined in the late 1940s to distinguish older wide-groove records from Columbia's new 'micro-groove' LP technology.
